Privatized Graph Federated Learning

Elsa Rizk1,  Stefan Vlaski2,  and Ali H. Sayed1 1The authors are with the School of Engineering, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (e-mail: {elsa.rizk; ali.sayed}@epfl.ch).2The author is with the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College London (e-mail: s.vlaski@imperial.ac.uk). A short conference article dealing with an earlier version of this work without extended arguments and proofs appears in [1].
This work has been submitted for review.
Abstract

Federated learning is a semi-distributed algorithm, where a server communicates with multiple dispersed clients to learn a global model. The federated architecture is not robust and is sensitive to communication and computational overloads due to its one-master multi-client structure. It can also be subject to privacy attacks targeting personal information on the communication links. In this work, we introduce graph federated learning (GFL), which consists of multiple federated units connected by a graph. We then show how graph homomorphic perturbations can be used to ensure the algorithm is differentially private. We conduct both convergence and privacy theoretical analyses and illustrate performance by means of computer simulations.

Index Terms:
federated learning, graph learning, privatized learning, differntial privacy

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [2] emerged in recent years as a solution to distributed machine learning where users no longer need to send their data to a server for training. Instead, data remains local, and training happens in collaboration between different clients and the server. Compared to a fully decentralized solution, communication occurs between the server and the clients (or agents), instead of directly between the agents themselves. Such a solution is advantageous in the sense that users no longer need to worry about sharing their data with an unknown party, and the high cost of sending all their raw data is eliminated. In this way, the data stays locally safe on a user’s device, and no extra communication cost is incurred for transferring the data remotely. However, such a distributed architecture is not robust to communication failures and computational overloads, nor it is immune to privacy attacks when agents are required to share their local updates. In standard FL, millions of users can be connected to one server at a time. This means one server will need to be responsible for the communication with all clients with significant computational burden, thus rendering the system susceptible to communication failures. Furthermore, whether clients send their gradient updates or their local models, information about their data can be inferred from the exchanges and leaked [3, 4, 5, 6]. Consider for instance the logistic risk; the gradient of the loss function is a constant multiple of the feature vector. Thus, even though the actual data samples are not sent to the server, information about them can still be inferred from the gradient updates or the models.

These considerations motivate us to propose an architecture for federated learning with privacy guarantees. In particular, we introduce the graph federated architecture, which consists of multiple servers, and we privatize the algorithm by ensuring the communication ocuring between the servers and the clients is secure. Graph homomorphic perturbations, which were initially introduced in [7], focus on the communication between servers. They are based on adding correlated noise to the messages sent between servers such that the noise cancels out if we were to take the average of all messages across all servers. As for the privatization between the clients and their servers, we rely on already existing solutions, mainly [8]. It is a secret sharing method that guarantees messages sent by clients are encoded and is equivalent to masking the message. While the two protocols rely on different tools, both make sure the effect of the added noise is reduced.

Other works have also contributed to addressing the same challenges we are considering in this work, albeit differently. For example, the work [9] introduces a hierarchical architecture, where it is assumed there are multiple servers connected in a tree structure. Such a solution still has one main server and thus faces the same robustness problem as FL. The graph federated learning architecture in this work (and which appeared in the earlier conference publication [1]) is a more general structure. The work [10] generalizes the standard distributed learning framework to include local updates, while [11] has a similar architecture to the GFL architecture proposed earlier in [1], it nevertheless does not deal with privacy and employs different objective functions and a different learning algorithm based on the alternating direction method of multipliers. Likewise, a plethora of solutions exist that relate to privacy issues. These methods may be split into two sub-groups: those using random perturbations to ensure a certain level of differential privacy [12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20], or those that rely on cryptographic methods [8, 21, 22, 23, 24]. Both have their advantages and disadvantages. While differential privacy is easy to implement, it hinders the performance of the algorithm by reducing the model utility. As for cryptographic methods, they are generally harder to implement since they require more computational and communication power [25, 26]. Furthremore, they restrict the number of participating users. Thus, moving forward, we believe a scheme fusing the two paradigms would be best.

II Graph Federated Architecture

In the graph federated architecture, which we initially introduced in [1], we consider P𝑃P federated units connected by a graph structure. Each federated unit consists of a server and a set of K𝐾K agents. Thus, the overall architecture can be represented as a graph depicted in Figure 1. We denote the combination matrix connecting the servers by A∈ℝP×P𝐴superscriptℝ𝑃𝑃A\in\mathbb{R}^{P\times P}, and we write am​psubscript𝑎𝑚𝑝a_{mp} to refer to the elements of A𝐴A. We assume each agent of every server has its own dataset {xp,k,n}n=1Np,ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑝𝑘𝑛𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑝𝑘\{x_{p,k,n}\}_{n=1}^{N_{p,k}} that is non-iid when compared to the other agents. The subscript p𝑝p refers to the federated unit, k𝑘k to the agent, and n𝑛n to the data sample.

With this architecture, we associate a convex optimization problem that will take into account the cost function at each federated unit. Thus, the optimization goal is to find the optimal global model wosuperscript𝑤𝑜w^{o} that minimizes an average empirical risk:

wo​=Δ​argminw∈ℝM1P​∑p=1P1K​∑k=1KJp,k​(w),superscript𝑤𝑜Δsubscriptargmin𝑤superscriptℝ𝑀1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐽𝑝𝑘𝑤w^{o}\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\operatorname*{argmin}_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{M}}\frac{1}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}J_{p,k}(w), (1)

where each individual cost is an empirical risk defined over the local loss functions Qp,k​(⋅;⋅)subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘⋅⋅Q_{p,k}(\cdot;\cdot):

Jp,k​(w)​=Δ​1Np,k​∑n=1Np,kQp,k​(w;xp,k,n).subscript𝐽𝑝𝑘𝑤Δ1subscript𝑁𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑝𝑘subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘𝑤subscript𝑥𝑝𝑘𝑛J_{p,k}(w)\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\frac{1}{N_{p,k}}\sum_{n=1}^{N_{p,k}}Q_{p,k}(w;x_{p,k,n}). (2)

To solve problem (1) each federated unit p𝑝p runs the standard federated averaging (FedAvg) algorithm [2]. An iteration i𝑖i of the algorithm consists of the server p𝑝p selecting a subset of L𝐿L participating agents ℒp,isubscriptℒ𝑝𝑖\mathcal{L}_{p,i}. Then, in parallel, each agent runs a series of stochastic gardient descent (SGD) steps. We call these local steps epochs, and denote an epoch by the letter e𝑒e and the total number of epochs by Ep,ksubscript𝐸𝑝𝑘E_{p,k}. The sampled data point at an agent k𝑘k in the federated unit p𝑝p during the et​hsuperscript𝑒𝑡ℎe^{th} epoch of iteration i𝑖i is denoted by b𝑏b. Thus, during an iteration i𝑖i, each participating agent k∈ℒp,i𝑘subscriptℒ𝑝𝑖k\in\mathcal{L}_{p,i} updates the last model 𝒘p,i−1subscript𝒘𝑝𝑖1\bm{w}_{p,i-1} and sends its new model 𝒘p,k,Ep,ksubscript𝒘𝑝𝑘subscript𝐸𝑝𝑘\bm{w}_{p,k,E_{p,k}} to the server after Ep,ksubscript𝐸𝑝𝑘E_{p,k} epochs. During a single epoch e𝑒e, the agent updates its current local model wp,k,e−1subscript𝑤𝑝𝑘𝑒1w_{p,k,e-1} by running a single SGD step. Thus, an agent repeats the following adaptation step for e=1,2,⋯,Ep,k𝑒12⋯subscript𝐸𝑝𝑘e=1,2,\cdots,E_{p,k}:

𝒘p,k,e=subscript𝒘𝑝𝑘𝑒absent\displaystyle\bm{w}_{p,k,e}= 𝒘p,k,e−1−μEp,k​∇w𝖳Qp,k​(𝒘p,k,e−1;𝒙p,k,b),subscript𝒘𝑝𝑘𝑒1𝜇subscript𝐸𝑝𝑘subscript∇superscript𝑤𝖳subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘subscript𝒘𝑝𝑘𝑒1subscript𝒙𝑝𝑘𝑏\displaystyle\>\bm{w}_{p,k,e-1}-\frac{\mu}{E_{p,k}}\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}Q_{p,k}(\bm{w}_{p,k,e-1};\bm{x}_{p,k,b}), (3)

with 𝒙p,k,bsubscript𝒙𝑝𝑘𝑏\bm{x}_{p,k,b} be the sampled data of agent k𝑘k in federated unit p𝑝p, and 𝒘p,k,0=𝒘p,i−1subscript𝒘𝑝𝑘0subscript𝒘𝑝𝑖1\bm{w}_{p,k,0}=\bm{w}_{p,i-1}. After all the participating agents k∈ℒp,i𝑘subscriptℒ𝑝𝑖k\in\mathcal{L}_{p,i} run all their epochs, the server aggregates their final models 𝒘p,k,Ep,ksubscript𝒘𝑝𝑘subscript𝐸𝑝𝑘\bm{w}_{p,k,E_{p,k}}, which we rename as 𝒘p,k,isubscript𝒘𝑝𝑘𝑖\bm{w}_{p,k,i} since it is the final local model at iteration i𝑖i:

𝝍p,i=1L​∑k∈ℒp,i𝒘p,k,i.subscript𝝍𝑝𝑖1𝐿subscript𝑘subscriptℒ𝑝𝑖subscript𝒘𝑝𝑘𝑖\displaystyle\bm{\psi}_{p,i}=\frac{1}{L}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{L}_{p,i}}\bm{w}_{p,k,i}. (4)

Next, at the server level, these estimates are combined across neighbourhoods using a diffusion type strategy, where we first consider the previous steps (3) and (4) as the adaptation step and the following step as the combination step:

𝒘p,i=∑m∈𝒩pap​m​𝝍m,i.subscript𝒘𝑝𝑖subscript𝑚subscript𝒩𝑝subscript𝑎𝑝𝑚subscript𝝍𝑚𝑖\bm{w}_{p,i}=\sum_{m\in\mathcal{N}_{p}}a_{pm}\bm{\psi}_{m,i}. (5)

To introduce privacy, the models communicated at each round between the agents and the servers need to be encrypted in some way. We could either apply secure multiparty computation (SMC) tools, like secret sharing, or use differential privacy. We focus on differential privacy or masking tools that can be represented by added noise. Thus, we let agent 1 in federated unit 2 add a noise component 𝒈2,1,isubscript𝒈21𝑖\bm{g}_{2,1,i} to its final model 𝒘2,1,isubscript𝒘21𝑖\bm{w}_{2,1,i} at iteration i𝑖i, and then let serever 222 add 𝒈12,isubscript𝒈12𝑖\bm{g}_{12,i} to the message 𝝍2,isubscript𝝍2𝑖\bm{\psi}_{2,i} it sends to server 1. More generally, we denote by 𝒈p​m,isubscript𝒈𝑝𝑚𝑖\bm{g}_{pm,i} the noise added to the message sent by server m𝑚m to server p𝑝p at iteration i𝑖i. Similarly, we denote by 𝒈p,k,isubscript𝒈𝑝𝑘𝑖\bm{g}_{p,k,i} the noise added to the model sent by agent k𝑘k to server p𝑝p during the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} iteration. We use unseparated subscripts p​m𝑝𝑚pm for the inter-server noise components to point out their ability to be combined into a matrix structure. Contrarily, the agent-server noise components’ subscripts are separated by a comma to highlight a hierarchical structure. Thus, the privatized algorithm can be written as a client update step (6), a server aggregation step (7), and a server combination step (8):

𝝍p,isubscript𝝍𝑝𝑖\displaystyle\bm{\psi}_{p,i} =1L​∑k∈ℒp,i𝒘p,k,i+𝒈p,k,i,absent1𝐿subscript𝑘subscriptℒ𝑝𝑖subscript𝒘𝑝𝑘𝑖subscript𝒈𝑝𝑘𝑖\displaystyle=\frac{1}{L}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{L}_{p,i}}\bm{w}_{p,k,i}+\bm{g}_{p,k,i}, (7)

III Performance Analysis

In this section, we show a list of results on the performance of the algorithm. We study the convergence of the privatized algorithm (6)-(8), and examine the effect of privatization on performance.

III-A Modeling Conditions

To go forward with our analysis, we require certain reasonable assumptions on the graph structure and cost functions.

Assumption 1 (Combination matrix).

The combination matrix A𝐴A describing the graph is symmetric and doubly-stochastic, i.e.:

ap​m=am​p,∑m=1Pam​p=1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑎𝑝𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑃subscript𝑎𝑚𝑝1a_{pm}=a_{mp},\quad\sum_{m=1}^{P}a_{mp}=1. (10)

Furthermore, the graph is strongly-connected and A𝐴A satisfies:

ι2​=Δ​ρ​(A−1P​𝟙𝟙𝖳)<1.subscript𝜄2Δ𝜌𝐴1𝑃superscript11𝖳1\iota_{2}\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\rho\left(A-\frac{1}{P}\mathbbm{1}\mathbbm{1}^{\sf T}\right)<1. (11)

∎

Assumption 2 (Convexity and smoothness).

The empirical risks Jp,k​(⋅)subscript𝐽𝑝𝑘⋅J_{p,k}(\cdot) are ν−s​t​r​o​n​g​l​y𝜈𝑠𝑡𝑟𝑜𝑛𝑔𝑙𝑦\nu-strongly convex with ν>0𝜈0\nu>0, and the loss functions Qp,k​(⋅;⋅)subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘⋅⋅Q_{p,k}(\cdot;\cdot) are convex, namely:

Furthermore, the loss functions have δ−limit-from𝛿\delta-Lipschitz continuous gradients:

‖∇w𝖳Qp,k​(w2;xp,k,n)−∇w𝖳Qp,k​(w1;xp,k,n)‖≤δ​‖w2−w1‖.normsubscript∇superscript𝑤𝖳subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘subscript𝑤2subscript𝑥𝑝𝑘𝑛subscript∇superscript𝑤𝖳subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘subscript𝑤1subscript𝑥𝑝𝑘𝑛𝛿normsubscript𝑤2subscript𝑤1\|\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}Q_{p,k}(w_{2};x_{p,k,n})-\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}Q_{p,k}(w_{1};x_{p,k,n})\|\leq\delta\|w_{2}-w_{1}\|. (14)

∎

We also require a bound on the difference between the global optimal model wosuperscript𝑤𝑜w^{o} and the local optimal models wp,kosubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑜𝑝𝑘w^{o}_{p,k} that optimize Jp,k​(⋅)subscript𝐽𝑝𝑘⋅J_{p,k}(\cdot). This assumption is used to bound the gradient noise and the incremental noise defined further ahead. It is not a restrictive assumption, and it imposes a condition on when collaboration is sensical among different agents. In other words, since the agents have non-iid data, sometimes their optimal models are too different and collaboration would hurt their individual performance. For example, when considering recommender systems, people in the same country are more likely to get the same movie recommended as opposed to accross different countries. This means, people of the same country might have different models but relatively close contrary to different countries.

Assumption 3 (Model drifts).

The distance of each local model wp,kosuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑝𝑘𝑜w_{p,k}^{o} to the global model wosuperscript𝑤𝑜w^{o} is uniformly bounded, ‖wo−wp,ko‖≤ξnormsuperscript𝑤𝑜superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑝𝑘𝑜𝜉\|w^{o}-w_{p,k}^{o}\|\leq\xi.

III-B Network Centroid Convergence

We study the convergence of the algorithm from the network centroid’s 𝒘c,isubscript𝒘𝑐𝑖\bm{w}_{c,i} perspective:

𝒘c,i​=Δ​1P​∑p=1P𝒘p,i.subscript𝒘𝑐𝑖Δ1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃subscript𝒘𝑝𝑖\bm{w}_{c,i}\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\frac{1}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\bm{w}_{p,i}. (15)

We estimate the first and second-order moments of the gradient noise in the following lemma. To do so, we use the fact, shown in previous work (Lemma 1 in [27]), that the individual gradient noise is zero-mean with a bounded second order moment:

Lemma 1 (Estimation of first and second-order moments of the gradient noise).

The gradient noise defined in (17) is zero-mean and has a bounded second-order moment:

𝔼​{‖𝒔i‖2|ℱi−1}𝔼conditionalsuperscriptnormsubscript𝒔𝑖2subscriptℱ𝑖1\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\|\bm{s}_{i}\|^{2}|\mathcal{F}_{i-1}\right\} ≤βs2​‖𝒘~c,i−1‖2+σs2absentsuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑠2superscriptnormsubscript~𝒘𝑐𝑖12superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2\displaystyle\leq\beta_{s}^{2}\|\widetilde{\bm{w}}_{c,i-1}\|^{2}+\sigma_{s}^{2}
+2P​∑p=1Pβs,p2​‖𝒘p,i−1−𝒘c,i−1‖22𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑠𝑝2superscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑝𝑖1subscript𝒘𝑐𝑖12\displaystyle\quad+\frac{2}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\beta_{s,p}^{2}\|\bm{w}_{p,i-1}-\bm{w}_{c,i-1}\|^{2} (28)

where the constants βs2superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑠2\beta_{s}^{2} and σs2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2\sigma_{s}^{2} are given by:

βs2superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑠2\displaystyle\beta_{s}^{2} =Δ​2P​∑p=1Pβs,p2,σs2​=Δ​1P​∑p=1Pσs,p2.Δ2𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑠𝑝2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2Δ1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠𝑝2\displaystyle\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\frac{2}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\beta_{s,p}^{2},\quad\sigma_{s}^{2}\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\frac{1}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\sigma_{s,p}^{2}. (29)
Proof.

The above result follows from applying the Jensen’s inequality and the bounds on the per-unit gradient noise 𝒔p,isubscript𝒔𝑝𝑖\bm{s}_{p,i}. ∎

The new term found in the bound of the gradient term is what we call the network disagreement:

1P​∑p=1P‖𝒘p,i−𝒘c,i‖2.1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃superscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑝𝑖subscript𝒘𝑐𝑖2\frac{1}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\|\bm{w}_{p,i}-\bm{w}_{c,i}\|^{2}. (30)

It captures the difference in the path taken by the individual models versus the network centroid. We bound this difference in Lemma 3. Lemma 2 (Estimation of second-order moment of the incremental noise).

The incremental noise defined in (20) has a bounded second-order moment:

Proof.

Proof.

Thus, from the above lemma, we see that the individual models gravitate to the centroid model with an error introduced due to the added privatization. The effect of the added noise overpowers that of the gradient and incremental noise, since the later is on the order of the step-size.

Then, using the above result, we can establish the convergence of the centroid model to a neighbourhood of the true optimal model wosuperscript𝑤𝑜w^{o}.

Theorem 1 (Centroid MSE convergence).

Under Assumptions 1, 2 and 3, the network centroid converges to the optimal point wosuperscript𝑤𝑜w^{o} exponentially fast for a sufficiently small step-size μ𝜇\mu:

The main term in the above bound is the variance of the added noise with a dominating factor of μ−1superscript𝜇1\mu^{-1}, since:

which allows us to rewrite the bound as follows:

with 𝔼​‖𝒈‖2𝔼superscriptnorm𝒈2\mathbb{E}\|\bm{g}\|^{2} representing the variance of the total added noise, independent of time. While in general decreasing the step-size improves performance, the above result shows that this need not be the case with privatization. Thus, since the added noise impacts the model utility negatively, it is important to choose a privatization scheme that reduces the effect. In what follows, we look closely at such a scheme.

III-C Graph Homomorphic Perturbations

We consider a specific privatization scheme and specialize the above results. The goal of the scheme is to remove the O​(μ−1)𝑂superscript𝜇1O(\mu^{-1}) term from the MSE bounds. Thus, we wish to cancel out the total added noise amongst servers, i.e.:

∑p,m=1Pap​m​𝒈p​m,i=0.superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑚1𝑃subscript𝑎𝑝𝑚subscript𝒈𝑝𝑚𝑖0\sum_{p,m=1}^{P}a_{pm}\bm{g}_{pm,i}=0. (46)

To achieve this, we introduce graph homomorphic perturbations [7] defined as follows. We assume each server p𝑝p draws a sample 𝒈p,isubscript𝒈𝑝𝑖\bm{g}_{p,i} independently from the Laplace distribution L​a​p​(0,σg/2)𝐿𝑎𝑝0subscript𝜎𝑔2Lap(0,\sigma_{g}/\sqrt{2}) with variance σg2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2\sigma_{g}^{2}. Server p𝑝p then sets the noise 𝒈m​p,isubscript𝒈𝑚𝑝𝑖\bm{g}_{mp,i} added to the message sent to its neighbour m𝑚m as:

𝒈m​p,i={𝒈p,im≠p−1−ap​pap​p​𝒈p,i.subscript𝒈𝑚𝑝𝑖casessubscript𝒈𝑝𝑖𝑚𝑝1subscript𝑎𝑝𝑝subscript𝑎𝑝𝑝subscript𝒈𝑝𝑖otherwise\bm{g}_{mp,i}=\begin{cases}\bm{g}_{p,i}&m\neq p\\ -\frac{1-a_{pp}}{a_{pp}}\bm{g}_{p,i}.\end{cases} (47)

Furthermore, utilizing secret sharing methods, we can cancel out the noise added by clients at the server:

1L​∑k∈ℒp,i𝒈p,k,i=0.1𝐿subscript𝑘subscriptℒ𝑝𝑖subscript𝒈𝑝𝑘𝑖0\frac{1}{L}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{L}_{p,i}}\bm{g}_{p,k,i}=0. (48)

One example of such methods is Diffie-Hellman key exchange [28], where every pair of agents shares a secret key in order to securely communicate over a public channel. In the federated learning scenario, we wish to add noise to the messages sent to the server in such a way they cancel out at the server. Thus, we use the shared secret key among pairs of agents to generate the added noise that will cancel out at the server. To generate these shared secret keys, we assume we have a public generator v𝑣v and a prime modulous t𝑡t. Then, each agent has a secret key, say agent 1 has c𝑐c and a public key vcsuperscript𝑣𝑐v^{c}, which is broadcast. Next, each client raises all the public keys it receives from the other agents by its local secret key in order to get a shared secret key with every other agent. This allows every pair of agents to use their shared secret key as a seed to a pseudo-random generator to generate the noise.

Thus, with such a scheme, the noise components proportional to O​(μ−1)𝑂superscript𝜇1O(\mu^{-1}) cancel out in the error recursions, and the remaining error introduced by the noise is controlled by the step-size. Thus, its effect can be mitigated by using a smaller step-size.

Corollary 1 (Centroid MSE convergence under graph homomorphic perturbations).

Under Assumptions 1, 2 and 3, the network centroid with graph homomorphic perturbations converges to the optimal point wosuperscript𝑤𝑜w^{o} exponentially fast for a sufficiently small step-size μ𝜇\mu:

𝔼​‖𝒘~c,i‖2≤𝔼superscriptnormsubscript~𝒘𝑐𝑖2absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\widetilde{\bm{w}}_{c,i}\|^{2}\leq λc​𝔼​‖𝒘~c,i−1‖2+μ2​σs2+O​(μ2)​ξ2+O​(μ3)​σq2subscript𝜆𝑐𝔼superscriptnormsubscript~𝒘𝑐𝑖12superscript𝜇2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2𝑂superscript𝜇2superscript𝜉2𝑂superscript𝜇3superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑞2\displaystyle\lambda_{c}\mathbb{E}\|\widetilde{\bm{w}}_{c,i-1}\|^{2}+\mu^{2}\sigma_{s}^{2}+O(\mu^{2})\xi^{2}+O(\mu^{3})\sigma_{q}^{2}
+O​(μ)P​∑p=1P𝔼​‖𝒘p,i−1−𝒘c,i−1‖2.𝑂𝜇𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑝𝑖1subscript𝒘𝑐𝑖12\displaystyle+\frac{O(\mu)}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\mathbb{E}\|\bm{w}_{p,i-1}-\bm{w}_{c,i-1}\|^{2}. (49)

Then, letting i𝑖i tend to infinity, we get:

lim supi→∞𝔼​‖𝒘~c,i‖2≤subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑖𝔼superscriptnormsubscript~𝒘𝑐𝑖2absent\displaystyle\limsup_{i\to\infty}\mathbb{E}\|\widetilde{\bm{w}}_{c,i}\|^{2}\leq μ2​σs2+O​(μ2)​ξ2+O​(μ3)​σq21−λcsuperscript𝜇2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2𝑂superscript𝜇2superscript𝜉2𝑂superscript𝜇3superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑞21subscript𝜆𝑐\displaystyle\frac{\mu^{2}\sigma_{s}^{2}+O(\mu^{2})\xi^{2}+O(\mu^{3})\sigma_{q}^{2}}{1-\lambda_{c}}
+∑p=1PO​(1)​σg,p2+O​(μ).superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃𝑂1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔𝑝2𝑂𝜇\displaystyle+\sum_{p=1}^{P}O(1)\sigma_{g,p}^{2}+O(\mu). (50)
Proof.

Starting from (1), and replacing 𝔼​‖𝒈‖2=0𝔼superscriptnorm𝒈20\mathbb{E}\|\bm{g}\|^{2}=0 because 𝒈i=0subscript𝒈𝑖0\bm{g}_{i}=0, we get the final result. ∎

IV Privacy Analysis

We study the privacy of the algorithm in terms of differential privacy. We focus on graph homomorphic perturbations and show that the adopted scheme is differentially private. To do so, we first define what it means for an algorithm to be ϵ−limit-fromitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differentially private. Therefore, without loss of generality, assume agent 111 in federated unit 111 decides to not participate, and its data samples x1,1subscript𝑥11x_{1,1} are replaced by a new set x1,1′subscriptsuperscript𝑥′11x^{\prime}_{1,1} with a different distribution. Then, with the new data, the algorithm takes a different path. We denote the new models by 𝒘p,k,i′subscriptsuperscript𝒘′𝑝𝑘𝑖\bm{w}^{\prime}_{p,k,i}. The idea behind differential privacy is that an outside observant should not be able to distinguish between the two trajectories 𝒘p,k,isubscript𝒘𝑝𝑘𝑖\bm{w}_{p,k,i} and 𝒘p,k,i′subscriptsuperscript𝒘′𝑝𝑘𝑖\bm{w}^{\prime}_{p,k,i} and conclude whether agent one participated in the training. More formally, differential privacy is defined bellow.

Definition 1 (ϵ​(i)−limit-fromitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon(i)-Differential Privacy).

We say that the algorithm given in (6)–(8) is ϵ​(i)−limit-fromitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon(i)-differentially private for server p𝑝p at time i𝑖i if the following condition holds:

ℙ​({{𝝍p,j+𝒈p​m,j}m∈𝒩p∖{p}}j=0i|ℱi)ℙ​({{𝝍p,j′+𝒈p​m,j}m∈𝒩p∖{p}}j=0i|ℱi)≤eϵ​(i).ℙconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝍𝑝𝑗subscript𝒈𝑝𝑚𝑗𝑚subscript𝒩𝑝𝑝𝑗0𝑖subscriptℱ𝑖ℙconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝝍′𝑝𝑗subscript𝒈𝑝𝑚𝑗𝑚subscript𝒩𝑝𝑝𝑗0𝑖subscriptℱ𝑖superscript𝑒italic-ϵ𝑖\frac{\mathbb{P}\left(\left\{\left\{\bm{\psi}_{p,j}+\bm{g}_{pm,j}\right\}_{m\in\mathcal{N}_{p}\setminus\{p\}}\right\}_{j=0}^{i}\bigg{|}\mathcal{F}_{i}\right)}{\mathbb{P}\left(\left\{\left\{\bm{\psi}^{\prime}_{p,j}+\bm{g}_{pm,j}\right\}_{m\in\mathcal{N}_{p}\setminus\{p\}}\right\}_{j=0}^{i}\bigg{|}\mathcal{F}_{i}\right)}\leq e^{\epsilon(i)}. (51)

∎

Thus, the above definition states that minimaly varried trajectories have comparable probabilities. In addition, the smaller the value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is, the higher the privacy guarantee will be. Thus, the goal will be to decrease ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon as long as the model utility is not strongly affected.

Next, in order to show that the algorithm is differentially private, we require the sensitivity of the alogorithm. It captures the effect of a change in an input variable on the output. Thus, we write:

Δ​(i)Δ𝑖\displaystyle\Delta(i) =maxp,k⁡‖𝒘p,k,i−𝒘p,k,i′‖absentsubscript𝑝𝑘normsubscript𝒘𝑝𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘′𝑝𝑘𝑖\displaystyle=\max_{p,k}\|\bm{w}_{p,k,i}-\bm{w}^{\prime}_{p,k,i}\|
=‖𝒘1,1,i−𝒘1,1,i′‖absentnormsubscript𝒘11𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘′11𝑖\displaystyle=\|\bm{w}_{1,1,i}-\bm{w}^{\prime}_{1,1,i}\|
=μ​‖∑j=0i−1∇w𝖳J1,1^​(𝒘1,j)−∇w𝖳J1,1^​(𝒘1,j′)‖absent𝜇normsuperscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑖1^subscript∇superscript𝑤𝖳subscript𝐽11subscript𝒘1𝑗^subscript∇superscript𝑤𝖳subscript𝐽11subscriptsuperscript𝒘′1𝑗\displaystyle=\mu\left\|\sum_{j=0}^{i-1}\widehat{\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}J_{1,1}}(\bm{w}_{1,j})-\widehat{\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}J_{1,1}}(\bm{w}^{\prime}_{1,j})\right\|
≤2​μ​B​i,absent2𝜇𝐵𝑖\displaystyle\leq 2\mu Bi, (52)

where the inequality follows from the triangle inequality and the below result in Lemma 4 on the bound of the gradients evaluated at the models resulting from the algorithm. Thus, a single change in the input data will change the trajectory by at most 2​μ​B​i2𝜇𝐵𝑖2\mu Bi, where B𝐵B is some constant bound on the gradients. The sensitivity is also linearly proportional to the iteration; thus as time passes the two trajectories diverge.

Lemma 4 (Bounded gradients along algorithm trajectory).

Assuming the loss functions Qp,k​(⋅;⋅)subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘⋅⋅Q_{p,k}(\cdot;\cdot) satisfy Assumption 2, then they have bounded gradients along the trajectory of the algorithm: ‖∇w𝖳Qp,k​(𝐰;xp,k,n)‖≤B,normsubscript∇superscript𝑤𝖳subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘𝐰subscript𝑥𝑝𝑘𝑛𝐵\|\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}Q_{p,k}(\bm{w};x_{p,k,n})\|\leq B, for some constant B that depends on the starting point of the algorithm w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} and the local and global optimal models.

Proof.

Proof found in Appendix E. ∎

Using the bound on the sensitivity and from the definition of differential privacy, we can finally show that the algorithm is differentially private.

Theorem 2 (Privacy of GFL algorithm).

If the algorithm (6)-(8) adopts graph homomorphic perturbations, then it is ϵ​(i)−limit-fromitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon(i)-differentially private, at time i𝑖i for a standard deviation of σg=2​μ​B​(1+i)​i/ϵ​(i)subscript𝜎𝑔2𝜇𝐵1𝑖𝑖italic-ϵ𝑖\sigma_{g}=\sqrt{2}\mu B(1+i)i/\epsilon(i).

Proof.

Proof found in Appendix F. ∎

Thus, the above theorem suggests, if we wish the algorithm to be ϵ​(i)−limit-fromitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon(i)-differentially private, then we need to choose the noise variance accordingly. The larger the variance is, the more private the algorithm will be. However, the longer the algorithm is run, we will require a larger noise variance to keep the same level of privacy guarantee. Said differently, if we fix the added noise, then as time passes, the algorithm becomes less private, and more information is leaked. However, with graph-homomorphic perturbations, we can afford to increase the varianve since its effect is constant on the MSE, and thus decreases the leakage.

V Experimental Analysis

We conduct a series of experiments to study the influence of privatization on the GFL algorithm. The aim of the experiments is to show the superior performance of graph homomorphic perturbations to random perturbations, and to study the effect of different parameters on the performance of the algorithm.

V-A Regression

We first start by studying a regression problem on simulated data. We do so for the tractability of the problem. We consider the quadratic loss that has a closed form solution, i.e., a formal expression for the true model wosuperscript𝑤𝑜w^{o} is known, which makes the calculation of the mean square error feasible and more accurate.

Therefore, consider a streaming feature vector 𝒖p,k,n∈ℝMsubscript𝒖𝑝𝑘𝑛superscriptℝ𝑀\bm{u}_{p,k,n}\in\mathbb{R}^{M} with output variable 𝒅p,k​(n)∈ℝsubscript𝒅𝑝𝑘𝑛ℝ\bm{d}_{p,k}(n)\in\mathbb{R} given by:

𝒅p,k​(n)=𝒖p,k,n𝖳​w⋆+𝒗p,k​(n),subscript𝒅𝑝𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑝𝑘𝑛𝖳superscript𝑤⋆subscript𝒗𝑝𝑘𝑛\bm{d}_{p,k}(n)=\bm{u}_{p,k,n}^{\sf T}w^{\star}+\bm{v}_{p,k}(n), (53)

where w⋆∈ℝMsuperscript𝑤⋆superscriptℝ𝑀w^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{M} is some generating model, and 𝒗p,k​(n)subscript𝒗𝑝𝑘𝑛\bm{v}_{p,k}(n) is some zero-mean Guassian random variable with σvp,k2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑣𝑝𝑘2\sigma_{v_{p,k}}^{2} variance and independent of 𝒖p,k,nsubscript𝒖𝑝𝑘𝑛\bm{u}_{p,k,n}. Then, the optimal model that solves the following problem:

minw⁡1P​∑p=1P1K​∑k=1K1Np,k​∑n=1Np,k‖𝒅p,k​(n)−𝒖p,k,n𝖳​w‖2+ρ​‖w‖2subscript𝑤1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑁𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑝𝑘superscriptnormsubscript𝒅𝑝𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑝𝑘𝑛𝖳𝑤2𝜌superscriptnorm𝑤2\min_{w}\frac{1}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{N_{p,k}}\sum_{n=1}^{N_{p,k}}\|\bm{d}_{p,k}(n)-\bm{u}_{p,k,n}^{\sf T}w\|^{2}+\rho\|w\|^{2} (54)

is found to be:

wo=(R^u+ρ​I)−1​(R^u​w⋆+r^u​v),superscript𝑤𝑜superscriptsubscript^𝑅𝑢𝜌𝐼1subscript^𝑅𝑢superscript𝑤⋆subscript^𝑟𝑢𝑣w^{o}=(\widehat{R}_{u}+\rho I)^{-1}(\widehat{R}_{u}w^{\star}+\widehat{r}_{uv}), (55)

where R^usubscript^𝑅𝑢\widehat{R}_{u} and r^u​vsubscript^𝑟𝑢𝑣\widehat{r}_{uv} are defined as:

R^usubscript^𝑅𝑢\displaystyle\widehat{R}_{u} =Δ​1P​∑p=1P1K​∑k=1K1Np,k​∑n=1Nk𝒖p,k,n​𝒖p,k,n𝖳,Δ1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑁𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑘subscript𝒖𝑝𝑘𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑝𝑘𝑛𝖳\displaystyle\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\frac{1}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{N_{p,k}}\sum_{n=1}^{N_{k}}\bm{u}_{p,k,n}\bm{u}_{p,k,n}^{\sf T}, (56)
r^u​vsubscript^𝑟𝑢𝑣\displaystyle\widehat{r}_{uv} =Δ​1P​∑p=1P1K​∑k=1K1Np,k​∑n=1Nk𝒗p,k​(n)​𝒖p,k,n.Δ1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑁𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑁𝑘subscript𝒗𝑝𝑘𝑛subscript𝒖𝑝𝑘𝑛\displaystyle\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\frac{1}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{N_{p,k}}\sum_{n=1}^{N_{k}}\bm{v}_{p,k}(n)\bm{u}_{p,k,n}. (57)

We consider P=𝑃absentP=10 units, each with K=100𝐾100K=100 total agents. We assume, Np,k=100subscript𝑁𝑝𝑘100N_{p,k}=100 for each agent. We randomly generate two-dimensional feature vectors 𝒖p,k​(n)subscript𝒖𝑝𝑘𝑛\bm{u}_{p,k}(n) from a Guassian random vector with zero-mean and a randomly generated covarinace matrix Rup,ksubscript𝑅subscript𝑢𝑝𝑘R_{u_{p,k}}. We then calculate the corresponding outputs according to (53). To make the data non-iid accross agents, we assume the covariance matrix Rup,ksubscript𝑅subscript𝑢𝑝𝑘R_{u_{p,k}} is different for each agent, as well as the variance σvp,k2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑣𝑝𝑘2\sigma_{v_{p,k}}^{2} of the added noise. When running the algorithm, we assume each unit samples at random L=11𝐿11L=11 agents, and each agent runs Ep,k∈[1,10]subscript𝐸𝑝𝑘110E_{p,k}\in[1,10] epochs and uses a mini-batch of Bp,k∈[5,10]subscript𝐵𝑝𝑘510B_{p,k}\in[5,10] samples.

We compare three algorithms: the standard GFL algorithm, the privatized GFL algorithm with random perturbations, and the privatized GFL with homomorphic perturbations. In the first set of simulations, we fix the step-size μ=0.7𝜇0.7\mu=0.7 and the regularization parameter ρ=0.1𝜌0.1\rho=0.1. We fix the variance of the added noise for privatization in both schemes to σg2=0.1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔20.1\sigma_{g}^{2}=0.1. We then plot the mean-square-deviation at each time step for the centroid model:

MSDi​=Δ​‖𝒘c,i−wo‖2,subscriptMSD𝑖Δsuperscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑐𝑖superscript𝑤𝑜2\mbox{\rm MSD}_{i}\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\|\bm{w}_{c,i}-w^{o}\|^{2}, (58)

as seen in Figure 2. We observe that the privatized GFL with random perturbations has lower performance compared to the other two algorithms. While, using homomorphic perturbations does not result in such a decay in performance. Thus, our suggested scheme does a good job at tracking the performance of the original GFL algorithm, while not compromising with the privacy level.

We next study the extent of the effect of the noise on the model utility. Thus, we run a series of experiments with varying added noise σg2={0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,10}superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔20.0010.010.11210\sigma_{g}^{2}=\{0.001,0.01,0.1,1,2,10\} for the two privatized GFL algorithms. We plot the resulting MSD curves in Figure 3(a). We obsereve for a fixed step-size, as we increase the variance, the MSD of the algorithm with random perturbations increases significantly as opposed to the algorithm with homomorphic perturbations. Thus, we conclude that the algorithm with random perturbtaions is more sensitive to the variance of the added noise. In fact, at some point, while using random perturbations, for some variance, the algorithm breaks down. While using graph homomorphic perturbations, delays that effect for much larger variance. In addition, as long as the step-size is small enough, we can always control the effect of the graph homomorphic perturbations.

However, if we were to look at the individual MSD for one federated unit, we would discover that the performance of the algorithm decays as the noise variance is increased. Nonetheless, it is not to the extent of random perturbations. We plot in Figure 3(b) the average individual MSD for the varying noise variance:

MSDavg,i​=Δ​1P​∑p=1P‖𝒘p,i−wo‖2.subscriptMSDavg𝑖Δ1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑃superscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑝𝑖superscript𝑤𝑜2\mbox{\rm MSD}_{\mbox{\rm avg},i}\>\overset{\Delta}{=}\>\frac{1}{P}\sum_{p=1}^{P}\|\bm{w}_{p,i}-w^{o}\|^{2}. (59)

We observe that for a fixed noise variance, homomorphic perturbations results in a better performance. Furthermore, as we increase the noise variance, the network disagreement increases for both schemes. This comes as no surprise and is in accordance with Lemma 3. Furthermore, as previously mentioned, graph homomorphic perturbations have the added value of not being negatively affected by the decrease in the step-size. In addition, even though the improvement does not seem significant, the source of the error of the two schemes is different. Furthemore, the information of the true model is distributed in the network and can be retrieved by running at the end of the learning algorithm a consensus-type step. At that point, the local models no longer contain information about the local data, and thus agents can safely share their models. However, when random perturbations are used, reconstruction is not possible since the information has been lost in the netwrok due to the added perturbations.

We next fix the noise variance σg2=0.1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔20.1\sigma_{g}^{2}=0.1 and varying the step-size μ={0.1,0.5,1,5}𝜇0.10.515\mu=\{0.1,0.5,1,5\}. According to Theorem 3, the MSD resulting from random perturbations includes an O​(μ−1)𝑂superscript𝜇1O(\mu^{-1}) term, which is not the case when using graph homomorphic perturbations. Thus, we expect a decrease in the step-size will not significantly affect the privatized algorithm with graph homomorphic perturbations as opposed to random perturbations. Indeed, as seen in Figure 4, as μ𝜇\mu is increased, the final MSD increases; this is probably due to the O​(μ)​σs2𝑂𝜇superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2O(\mu)\sigma_{s}^{2} term in the bound. In contrast, for significantly small or large μ𝜇\mu, the performance of the privatized algorithm with random perturbations decreases. In addition, what we observe for both privacy schemes, is that the rate of convergence slows down as we decrease the step-size. Thus, there exists an optimal step-size that achieves a good compromise between a fast convergence and a low MSD.

V-B Classification

We now focus on a classification problem applied to a dataset on click rate prediction of ads. We consider the Avazu click through dataset [29]. We split the 5101 data unequally among a total of 50 agents. We assume there are P=5𝑃5P=5 units each with K=10𝐾10K=10 agents. We add non-idd noise to the data at each agent to change their distributions. We again compare three algorithms: standard GFL, privatized GFL with homomorphic perturbations, and privatized GFL with random perturbations. We use a regularized logistic risk with regularization parameter ρ=0.03𝜌0.03\rho=0.03. We set the step-size μ=0.5𝜇0.5\mu=0.5. We repeat the algorithms for multiple levels of privacy. We then settle on a noise variance σg2=0.6superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔20.6\sigma_{g}^{2}=0.6 for which the privatized algorithm with random perturbations still converges. We plot in Figure 5 the testing error on a set of 256 clean samples that were not perturbed with noise to change their distributions. We use the centriod model learned during each iteration to calculate the corresponding testing error. We observe that the graph homorphic perturbations do not hinder the performance of the privatized model. As for random perturbations, they significantly reduce the utility of the learnt model.

VI Conclusion

In this work, we introduced graph federated learning and implemented an algorithm that guarantees privacy of the data in a differential privacy sense. We showed general privatization based on adding random perturbations to updates in federated learning have a negative effect on the performance of the algorithm. Random perturbations drive the algorithm farther away from the true optimal model. However, we showed by adding graph homomorphic perturbations, which exploit the graph structure, performance can be recovered with guaranteed privacy. We also showed that using dependent perturbations does not result in the same trade-off between privacy and efficiency. Thus, we no longer have to choose what to prioritize, and instead, we can have both a highly privatized algorithm with a good model utility.

where we define the diagonal matrix ΛΛ\Lambda with λpsubscript𝜆𝑝\lambda_{p} as entries on the diagonal. Then choosing μ𝜇\mu small enough such that λp<1subscript𝜆𝑝1\lambda_{p}<1 for every p𝑝p, we know the limit of ΛisuperscriptΛ𝑖\Lambda^{i} as i𝑖i goes to infinity is zero. Furthermore, if the eigenvalues of ΛΛ\Lambda are less than 1, which they are, then the geometric series converges to (I−Λ)−1superscript𝐼Λ1(I-\Lambda)^{-1}. Thus, we get the desired result.

∎

Appendix D Secondary Result: Bound on ‖𝒘~p,i‖normsubscript~𝒘𝑝𝑖\|\widetilde{\bm{w}}_{p,i}\|

In the theorem below we bound the ℓ2−limit-fromsubscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm of the error, which will be used to prove the boundedness of the gradients at every step of the algorithm.

Theorem 4 (Bounded ℓ2−limit-fromsubscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm of individual errors).

Under Assumptions 1, 2 and 3, the ℓ2−limit-fromsubscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm of the individual errors is bounded as follows for a sufficiently small step-size:

∎

Appendix E Proof of Lemma 4

Using Theorem 4 in Appendix D, we can bound the local gradients during each iteration as follows:

‖∇w𝖳Qp,k​(𝒘p,i;𝒙p,k,b)‖normsubscript∇superscript𝑤𝖳subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘subscript𝒘𝑝𝑖subscript𝒙𝑝𝑘𝑏\displaystyle\|\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}Q_{p,k}(\bm{w}_{p,i};\bm{x}_{p,k,b})\|
=∥∇w𝖳Qp,k(𝒘p,i;𝒙p,k,b))−∇w𝖳Qp,k(wo;𝒙p,k,b))\displaystyle=\|\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}Q_{p,k}(\bm{w}_{p,i};\bm{x}_{p,k,b}))-\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}Q_{p,k}(w^{o};\bm{x}_{p,k,b}))
+∇w𝖳Qp,k(wo;𝒙p,k,b))∥\displaystyle\quad+\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}Q_{p,k}(w^{o};\bm{x}_{p,k,b}))\|
≤δ​‖𝒘~p,i‖+‖∇w𝖳Qp,k​(wo;xp,k,max)‖,absent𝛿normsubscript~𝒘𝑝𝑖normsubscript∇superscript𝑤𝖳subscript𝑄𝑝𝑘superscript𝑤𝑜subscript𝑥𝑝𝑘max\displaystyle\leq\delta\|\widetilde{\bm{w}}_{p,i}\|+\|\nabla_{w^{{\sf T}}}Q_{p,k}(w^{o};x_{p,k,\text{max}})\|, (84)

where both terms on the right hand side are bounded.

Appendix F Proof of Theorem 2

To evaluate the probability distribution in definition 1, we note that the randomness of the models 𝝍p,jsubscript𝝍𝑝𝑗\bm{\psi}_{p,j} arises from the subsampling of the data for the calculation of the stochastic gradient at each iteration. Thus, given the subsampled dataset, the models are now deterministic and since the added noises 𝒈p​m,jsubscript𝒈𝑝𝑚𝑗\bm{g}_{pm,j} are Laplacian random variables, the distribution of the added noise over the neighbourhood of agent p𝑝p and over the iterations is given by:

ℙ​({{𝝍p,j+𝒈p​m,j}m∈𝒩p∖{p}}j=0i|ℱi)ℙconditionalsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝍𝑝𝑗subscript𝒈𝑝𝑚𝑗𝑚subscript𝒩𝑝𝑝𝑗0𝑖subscriptℱ𝑖\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\left\{\left\{\bm{\psi}_{p,j}+\bm{g}_{pm,j}\right\}_{m\in\mathcal{N}_{p}\setminus\{p\}}\right\}_{j=0}^{i}\bigg{|}\mathcal{F}_{i}\right)
=∏j=0i12​σg​exp⁡(−2σg​|𝝍p,j+𝒈p,j|)absentsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖12subscript𝜎𝑔2subscript𝜎𝑔subscript𝝍𝑝𝑗subscript𝒈𝑝𝑗\displaystyle=\prod_{j=0}^{i}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}\sigma_{g}}\exp\bigg{(}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sigma_{g}}|\bm{\psi}_{p,j}+\bm{g}_{p,j}|\bigg{)}
=12​σg​exp⁡(−2σg​∑j=0i|𝝍p,j+𝒈p,j|),absent12subscript𝜎𝑔2subscript𝜎𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑖subscript𝝍𝑝𝑗subscript𝒈𝑝𝑗\displaystyle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}\sigma_{g}}\exp\bigg{(}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sigma_{g}}\sum_{j=0}^{i}|\bm{\psi}_{p,j}+\bm{g}_{p,j}|\bigg{)}, (85)

and the ratio in Definition 1 is equal to:

exp⁡(−2σg​∑j=0i|𝝍p,j+𝒈p,j|−|𝝍p,j′+𝒈p,j|)2subscript𝜎𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑖subscript𝝍𝑝𝑗subscript𝒈𝑝𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝝍′𝑝𝑗subscript𝒈𝑝𝑗\displaystyle\exp\bigg{(}-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sigma_{g}}\sum_{j=0}^{i}|\bm{\psi}_{p,j}+\bm{g}_{p,j}|-|\bm{\psi}^{\prime}_{p,j}+\bm{g}_{p,j}|\bigg{)}
